BROADWAY

OLIVER ST





Dear Friends,

Kendel, Drew, Joshua and I are very pleased that
you have an interest in riding Maryland’s flagship
public transportation system . . . the Maryland
Transit Administration (MTA). This informative
MTA set of System Maps will help you navigate the
various options you have from Local Bus, Commuter
Bus, Light Rail, Metro Subway, MARC Train and
Mobility/Paratransit.

Whether you are riding our system for business
or pleasure, as a first-time rider or seasoned veteran,
we think you will find this publication useful in

information on MTA fares, riding policies, safety and
security advisories, how-to-ride suggestions, places
of interest, and useful telephone numbers.

But we think you will find the maps to be the
most impressive part of this publication. The System
Maps depict in colorful, easy-to-follow lines and
shields where all the MTA modes travel and their
connections to each other and to neighboring travel
modes such as Amtrak and Washington, D.C.’s
Metrorail System.

For work, school, shopping, sightseeing,
sporting and entertainment events, dining, and many
more destinations, the MTA is a great way to get
around. We thank you for riding the MTA and we
hope to see you onboard often.



Governor Robert L. Ehrlich, Jr.

reaching your destination. It is packed with important









MTA Local Bus e

The MTA operates more than 40 Local Bus lines
throughout the Baltimore region. Many Bus lines
connect with Light Rail, Metro Subway, and MARC
Trains.

When riding the Bus, please pay the fare as you
board. Exact fare is required. Touch the yellow strip
on the interior of the Bus to alert the operator that you
want to get off at the next stop. Please exit through the
rear door when possible. .

New Fareboxes on MTA Buses

All MTA Local Buses have been equipped with a
new farebox, which issues a magnetic Go Pass. Each
time you board a Bus slide your magnetic Go Pass
through the farebox swipe reader to validate your trip.
This magnetic Go Pass can also be used as a flash pass
on Light Rail.

Have exact fare in hand when boarding. Tell the
Bus operator what type of fare you wish to purchase
(Single Trip or Day Pass). Pay exact fare with bills
and/or coins, then grab your Go Pass (Day Passes only)
and go! Swipe your Go Pass through the swipe reader
when you transfer to other Buses. Weekly and Monthly
Go Passes can be purchased at participating Pass Sales
Outlets, online at www.mtamaryland.com or at the
MTA Transit Store at 6 St. Paul St., Baltimore.

Commuter Bus Service
[Weekdays Only]

There are more than 20 Commuter Bus routes
operating in central and southern Maryland which offer
convenient service to Baltimore and Washington, D.C.
in the morning and return service in the afternoon/
evening. Fares range from $2.75 to $6.50 one-way
and start at $93.50 for Monthly Passes. Reduced fares
($1.70-$5.45 one-way) are available for seniors and
people with disabilities with MTA-certified ID.

A Commuter Transit Link Card (TLC), for an
additional $50, extends Monthly Pass services to include
unlimited travel on WMATA Metrorail and Metrobuses in
the D.C. area. Commuter Monthly Passes and TLC Cards
are available online at www.mtamaryland.com.

Light Rail

Hours of Operation:
Mon.-Fri.: 6 a.m.-11 p.m.

Sat.: 7 a.m.-11 p.m., Sun./Holidays: 11 a.m.-7 p.m.

Light Rail operates at 10 to 30-minute intervals
between Hunt Valley, Downtown Baltimore, Orioles
and Ravens Camden Yards Sports Complex, to Crom-
well Station/Glen Burnie, and to the International
Pier (Concourse E) at BWI Airport and Penn Station
(Downtown). To get to BWI or Penn Station, a free
transfer may be necessary if the trip originates south of
Linthicum or north of Mount Royal. -





2005/2006

* Local Bus
-+ Light Rail
S G R T ALY



General Information

Smoking, eating, drinking and playing radios without
earphones are not permitted on MTA Buses, Light Rail,
and Metro Subway. Smoking and playing radios without
earphones are not permitted on MARC Trains.

Fares*
Local Bus, Light Rail or Metro Subway
Pass Type Senior/Disabled*| Students**
One-way
Day Pass
Weekly Pass
Monthly Pass

*Express Buses require an extra $.40 per ride.














Monthly Passes, Commuter Bus 10-Trip Tickets,
MARC tickets, and Transit Link Cards are available
online at www.mtamaryland.com.

*Seniors (65+)/Disabled require special ID cards.
Visitors from outside the MTA service area must show
either a Medicare or disability card and proof of
residency to qualify for the reduced fare.

**Students (K-12) should contact their school.
(Call 410-767-3441). Up to two children under age six

may ride free with each full-fare paying adult.

Service to Annual Events

Each year the MTA provides special Bus and Rail
services to the following events: Orioles baseball at
Camden Yards (April-September), Ravens NFL football at
M&T Bank Stadium (August-December), the
Preakness at Pimlico (3rd Saturday in May), Artscape
Festival (July), and the Maryland State Fair (11 days
ending Labor Day).

MTA Bicycle Policy

Bicycles are permitted on MTA Light Rail and Metro
Subway except on crowded trains. Some MTA Local
Buses are equipped with bicycle racks above the front
bumper. Folding bicycles in cases are allowed on MARC
Trains.

No bicycles are allowed on MTA Buses. You must
be 18 years of age or accompanied by an adult who is 18
years of age to bring a bicycle on MTA modes. No more
than two bicycles are permitted per wheelchair-accessible
transit vehicle.

Ridesharing/Commuter Assistance

The MTA Commuter Assistance Office can show you
how to cut your commuting expenses with several
different ridesharing options to suit your needs. For more
information call (410) 859-POOL, or toll-free
800-492-3757.

Il



L

When riding the Light Rail, please purchase a
ticket at a ticket vending machine before boarding the
train. Press the button on the outside of the train to gain
access. To exit, press the green button next to the door

Dear Friends,

Kendel, Drew, Joshua and I are very pleased that
you have an interest in riding Maryland’s flagship
public transportation system . . . the Maryland
Transit Administration (MTA). This informative
MTA set of System Maps will help you navigate the
various options you have from Local Bus, Commuter
Bus, Light Rail, Metro Subway, MARC Train and
Mobility/Paratransit.

Whether you are riding our system for business
or pleasure, as a first-time rider or seasoned veteran,
we think you will find this publication useful in

information on MTA fares, riding policies, safety and
security advisories, how-to-ride suggestions, places
of interest, and useful telephone numbers.

But we think you will find the maps to be the
most impressive part of this publication. The System
Maps depict in colorful, easy-to-follow lines and
shields where all the MTA modes travel and their
connections to each other and to neighboring travel
modes such as Amtrak and Washington, D.C.’s
Metrorail System.

For work, school, shopping, sightseeing,
sporting and entertainment events, dining, and many
more destinations, the MTA is a great way to get
around. We thank you for riding the MTA and we
hope to see you onboard often.



Governor Robert L. Ehrlich, Jr.

reaching your destination. It is packed with important









MTA Local Bus e

The MTA operates more than 40 Local Bus lines
throughout the Baltimore region. Many Bus lines
connect with Light Rail, Metro Subway, and MARC
Trains.

When riding the Bus, please pay the fare as you
board. Exact fare is required. Touch the yellow strip
on the interior of the Bus to alert the operator that you
want to get off at the next stop. Please exit through the
rear door when possible. .

New Fareboxes on MTA Buses

All MTA Local Buses have been equipped with a
new farebox, which issues a magnetic Go Pass. Each
time you board a Bus slide your magnetic Go Pass
through the farebox swipe reader to validate your trip.
This magnetic Go Pass can also be used as a flash pass
on Light Rail.

Have exact fare in hand when boarding. Tell the
Bus operator what type of fare you wish to purchase
(Single Trip or Day Pass). Pay exact fare with bills
and/or coins, then grab your Go Pass (Day Passes only)
and go! Swipe your Go Pass through the swipe reader
when you transfer to other Buses. Weekly and Monthly
Go Passes can be purchased at participating Pass Sales
Outlets, online at www.mtamaryland.com or at the
MTA Transit Store at 6 St. Paul St., Baltimore.

Commuter Bus Service
[Weekdays Only]

There are more than 20 Commuter Bus routes
operating in central and southern Maryland which offer
convenient service to Baltimore and Washington, D.C.
in the morning and return service in the afternoon/
evening. Fares range from $2.75 to $6.50 one-way
and start at $93.50 for Monthly Passes. Reduced fares
($1.70-$5.45 one-way) are available for seniors and
people with disabilities with MTA-certified ID.

A Commuter Transit Link Card (TLC), for an
additional $50, extends Monthly Pass services to include
unlimited travel on WMATA Metrorail and Metrobuses in
the D.C. area. Commuter Monthly Passes and TLC Cards
are available online at www.mtamaryland.com.

Light Rail

Hours of Operation:
Mon.-Fri.: 6 a.m.-11 p.m.

Sat.: 7 a.m.-11 p.m., Sun./Holidays: 11 a.m.-7 p.m.

Light Rail operates at 10 to 30-minute intervals
between Hunt Valley, Downtown Baltimore, Orioles
and Ravens Camden Yards Sports Complex, to Crom-
well Station/Glen Burnie, and to the International
Pier (Concourse E) at BWI Airport and Penn Station
(Downtown). To get to BWI or Penn Station, a free
transfer may be necessary if the trip originates south of
Linthicum or north of Mount Royal. -

General Information

Smoking, eating, drinking and playing radios without
earphones are not permitted on MTA Buses, Light Rail,
and Metro Subway. Smoking and playing radios without
earphones are not permitted on MARC Trains.

Pass Type Senior/Disabled*| Students**
One-way

*Express Buses require an extra $.40 per ride.














Monthly Passes, Commuter Bus 10-Trip Tickets,
MARC tickets, and Transit Link Cards are available
online at www.mtamaryland.com.

*Seniors (65+)/Disabled require special ID cards.
Visitors from outside the MTA service area must show
either a Medicare or disability card and proof of
residency to qualify for the reduced fare.

**Students (K-12) should contact their school.
(Call 410-767-3441). Up to two children under age six

may ride free with each full-fare paying adult.

Service to Annual Events

Each year the MTA provides special Bus and Rail
services to the following events: Orioles baseball at
Camden Yards (April-September), Ravens NFL football at
M&T Bank Stadium (August-December), the
Preakness at Pimlico (3rd Saturday in May), Artscape
Festival (July), and the Maryland State Fair (11 days
ending Labor Day).

MTA Bicycle Policy

Bicycles are permitted on MTA Light Rail and Metro
Subway except on crowded trains. Some MTA Local
Buses are equipped with bicycle racks above the front
bumper. Folding bicycles in cases are allowed on MARC
Trains.

No bicycles are allowed on MTA Buses. You must
be 18 years of age or accompanied by an adult who is 18
years of age to bring a bicycle on MTA modes. No more
than two bicycles are permitted per wheelchair-accessible
transit vehicle.

Ridesharing/Commuter Assistance

The MTA Commuter Assistance Office can show you
how to cut your commuting expenses with several
different ridesharing options to suit your needs. For more
information call (410) 859-POOL, or toll-free
800-492-3757.
